Message.Title: DRAM $4.78 ...UP 30% SINCE LAST WEEK...TARGET: $30+...RALLY TO DOUBLE DIGITS IS JUST GETTING STARTED...WAS $35 IN 2010 ON FAR LESS POTENTIAL
Message.Msg: DRAM highlights: - In business since 1967 – survived recessions/instability/uncertainty while many companies folded - Trades @ 0.2 X sales. The sector average is 1.5 times sales. - DRAM’s market cap is $8 million. - 1.4M shares float. Major Catalysts for Explosive Profitable Growth relative to its current valuation: 1) DRAM is and will benefit from skyrocketing memory prices (it's main core business for the last several decades). DRAM was almost profitable last quarter when memory prices were still near a bottom. Since the start of the quarter to be reported next week DRAM prices have increased about 70% 2) AMD and DRAM announced in May (5/8/2013 AMD Press Release and 5/12/2013 DRAMPress Release) that DRAM will begin manufacturing all new AMD Gamer Series memory modules and will provide it's RAMDisk software to drive all AMD Radeon products. The Gamer Series memory is compatible with AMD and Intel platforms, supporting both AMP and XMP memory profiles. Recent reviews rank AMD Gamer Series memory as the fastest and more reliable for gaming and other applications. "AMD Radeon RG2133 Gamer Series Memory is armed with features designed to outperform the competition on any task," said Roman Kyrychynskyi, product director, Graphics Business Unit, AMD. "Designed with multi-platform compatibility in mind, the AMD Radeon RG2133 brings cutting-edge technology, as well as uncompromising quality and compatibility for PC gamers. "AMD and Dataram have worked together to significantly enhance the dynamic background load-and-save feature in order to create a seamless, non-volatile RAMDisk experience," said Jason Caulkins, CTO, Dataram. "This underscores AMD and Dataram's continued dedication to delivering the highest-performing memory products. 3) DRAM is looking into diversifying with its RAMDisk software technology into many verticals needing faster and faster computing processing speeds such as the energy, banking, military, defense, government, NASA, medical, etc

Message.Title: Just another failure from obama, where were those weapons headed?
Message.Msg: PANAMA CITY (AP) — Panama's president said the country has seized a North Korean-flagged ship carrying what appeared to be ballistic missiles and other arms that had set sail from Cuba on its way to the Pacific. Panamanian President Ricardo Martinelli told RPC radio on Monday that the ship had been headed for North Korea. There were no immediate details on the quantity of arms aboard. Martinelli said the undeclared military cargo appeared to include missiles and non-conventional arms and the ship was violating United Nations resolutions against arms trafficking. Earlier, the president said on his Twitter account that the arms were "hidden in containers underneath the cargo of sugar." He offered no details but posted a photo of what appeared to be a green tubular object sitting inside a cargo container or the ship's hold.

Message.Title: Bank Of America Shares Hit 52-Week High, Analysts Expect Big Jump In Earnings
Message.Msg: 7/16/2013 @ 12:02PM EDT This August 19,2011 file photo shows a Bank of...Bank of America BAC -0.43% shares are experiencing a nice run a day before the bank reports second quarter earnings. Shares of the second largest bank hit a new 52-week high exceeding $14 this morning. That’s a level BofA shareholders haven’t seen since 2011. Analysts are expecting BofA to report net income of $2.9 billion, or $0.25 per share, on revenue of $22.8 billion tomorrow. That’s up 32% from last year when net income was $2.1 billion, or $0.19 a share, on revenue of $21.96 billion. At least one analyst sees BofA exceeding those estimates. Barclays BCS -0.8% analyst Jason Goldberg expects BofA to report $0.27 per share reflecting higher trading revenue.

Topic.Title: The honorable Eric Holder will take care of this Zimmerman punk

Message.Msg: Since you'd rather emote on this than deal in facts, here is the relevant statute from Florida: 776.032 Immunity from criminal prosecution and civil action for justifiable use of force.— (1) A person who uses force as permitted in s. 776.012, s. 776.013, or s. 776.031 is justified in using such force and is immune from criminal prosecution and civil action for the use of such force, unless the person against whom force was used is a law enforcement officer, as defined in s. 943.10(14), who was acting in the performance of his or her official duties and the officer identified himself or herself in accordance with any applicable law or the person using force knew or reasonably should have known that the person was a law enforcement officer. As used in this subsection, the term “criminal prosecution” includes arresting, detaining in custody, and charging or prosecuting the defendant. (3) The court shall award reasonable attorney’s fees, court costs, compensation for loss of income, and all expenses incurred by the defendant in defense of any civil action brought by a plaintiff if the court finds that the defendant is immune from prosecution as provided in subsection (1).

Message.Title: Free at last! Thank clod all muddy, free at last!
Message.Msg: When my cell door swung open last night at 0215 I was in deep REM. First thought was that the two hooded individuals were klansmen (a flashback from my 60s civil rights activism?); then I figured it was just my captors taking me to another water-boarding; but no, it was a pair of Anonymous sympathizers bent on busting me out. (The hoods turned out to be circus-circus pillowcases with mouth and eyehole cutouts). Anyway, they hurried me out to the lot, blindfolded me, and then subjected me to a 15-minute car ride and an interminable pair of simultaneous disconnected monologues, one on the subject of pharmaceutical options delivered by what might have been Vegas's oldest living showgirl, and the other on tampon praise and Indian killers delivered by some refugee from a star drek convention. Coulda been wikifreaks, coulda been hobbits, who cares besides the NSA and Clark County Corrections? Fortunately the geek must have been able to do simple math and had correctly calculated that with an extra 750 lbs of avgas on board, no way the Staggerwing was going to make it out of the RV park again. Without warning they dumped me out on the side of the road, and after a discrete interval I removed my blindfold and found myself in the RV dealership on W. Sahara at the head of the northbound I-15 on-ramp. The Staggerwing was resting gracefully atop a flatbed nearby, and after a quick preflight check (thanks for the 2 liter bottle of ice cold Pepsi, oh wise and hospitable Courtesy Hostess!) I started my takeoff run at the top of the ramp, got up just enough speed to 'hop' the dogleg at the freeway entrance, set 'er down again on the freeway, and hold her there until I rotated at a very delayed 110 knots (remind me to check the wheel bearings. Cleared the next overpass with feet to spare but took longer to reach 100 feet than it's taken BAC to reach 14 again. Made one low-level pass over the circus-circus pool to dump the tokens and kill the filtration system. Stay tuned...

Message.Title: Will Earnings Push Bank of America to Multiyear Highs?
Message.Msg: Bank of America (NYSE: BAC ) is scheduled to release its quarterly earnings report tomorrow, and with its report coming on the heels of similar announcements from many of its banking peers, B of A needs to demonstrate its ability to keep up with its rivals. As the best-performing stock in the Dow Jones Industrials (DJINDICES: ^DJI ) last year, B of A has already given investors high expectations for its future. In many ways, B of A has had an easy environment in which to recover.

Topic.Title: Excuse me Fish...

Message.Msg: Sorry I was unable to respond sooner, but last night got pretty hectic. Trust me, though, your comments were on my mind as I drifted off to sleep to catch a few winks before my successful jailbreak. You are a very perceptive individual, and very close to the mark as far as my motivations and purposes. All great art is refined and forged from the raw ore of human pathos; Toulousse-Latrec mined his raw material in Parisian bordellos; Guaguin in Polynesian fleshpits; Fellini found his among the freaks and misfits of the circus world; Twain among the ignorant Indian killers of frontier river towns; Faulkner in the decay of inbred southern gentry; and Springsteen in the tawdry industrial wasteland of Jersey. I've searched high and low for a better grade and source of ore, but to date none has rivaled the purity of evil, the naked avarice and unabashed moral bankruptcy found on this message board. ROTFLMAO in fact, according to my editor, an acknowledged master of the art of faint praise, the main difference between me and the aforementioned greats is that they displayed some sensitivity towards and kinship with their subjects.

Message.Msg: You know darned well she didn't elope with me; I'm pretty sure you two spent most of last night together, and the Beech barely had enough scrotes to handle that 2-liter pepsi and bag of circus-circus chips, never mind viewer's luscious but not insubstantial form. Please pass along my thanks to the wikifreaking hobbits who sprung me. I landed before dawn at a deserted dirt strip in the Four Corners region of Colorado, where another sympathizer met me with two 55 gallon drums of surplus SR-71 radar-absorbent flat black paint. Amazing the kind of deals you can find in those southwestern military aviation boneyards....anyway, I'm off to Boulder and Seattle to visit the local headshops and see what I can get for those meerschaums; then I'll be buying supplies and striking out on the next leg of my odyssey/rescue mission. If it wouldn't be putting you out, would you mind determining exactly how much the Snowman weighs, and what the earliest sighting of a flat, 1/2 mile long iceberg has been in the waters southeast of Iceland? I'd prefer the old ice-floe landing gambit to a non-stop Moscow-to-Reykjavik dash, but I think this mission's time constraints will exclude the former from a very short list of options. (check the great circle distance against the Beech's increased range and you'll see what I mean). ROTFLMAO off we go, into the wild blue......yonder....

Message.Title: Industrial Production Gives Economy a Welcome Sign
Message.Msg: The economy — which appears to have slowed sharply in the second quarter — received a welcome sign Tuesday morning: Industrial production rose slightly more than expected in June. The Federal Reserve reported that output at factories, mines, and utilities rose 0.3 percent last month, the largest increase since February and a significant jump from the relatively flat reading recorded in May.

Topic.Title: no matter how good earnings are the pps will fall tomorrowand the rest of today

Message.Msg: The fact that all stocks go up and down is why I deal mostly in corporate bonds. My goal is to increase my daily gains of accrued interest. I get $118 a day, everyday, 365 days a year. Each time I get an interest payout means my daily intake increases. I have enough cash in the account to raise that daily amount to $122 a day, everyday, 365 days a year. Do the math, that $43,070 for this year and after this year will increase $7.08 making the daily accrued interest of $125 a day, everyday, 365 days a year increasing my total for that year to $45,625. This will not change unless bonds become unavailable. I love it when people talk down bonds, lowering the par value on new bonds.

Topic.Title: Esteemed Fish (steamed fish in spanish)--

Message.Msg: Does this mean you've joined the unruly mob of torch-wielding Plato's Children trying to take it from me? ROTFLMAO and I was gonna buzz your commune in the morning and drop leaflets requesting humanitarian assistance and maybe a couple of Arizona State seatcovers for the beech...the stealth paint is bit depressing after that warm desert camo but what pleases the eye and spirit must sometimes yield to ....uh, just a second, this gila monster is being a little too forward for a first date... uh, yield to progress and evasion of radar. Felt kinda funny painting over the last registration numbers this evening, crossing the Rubicon so to speak. I bummed some white clay from one of the nice old Navaho pipe-making ladies, mixed it with water and cooking oil until I got it to a nice finger-painting consistency, and then smeared jolly rogers on the wings and fuselage as the sun was setting. I also added the beech's mission statement to the left cowling: "The Igloo in Bolivia or Bust!" Her new registration number? BAC50c. Yeehaw! A pre-dawn takeoff, a fast, down-and dirty run.....why, I think I feel a flashback comin' on.....I don't pay taxes 'cause I never file. I don't do business that don't make me smile I love my aeroplane 'cause she's got style....I'm a treetop flyer These bush league pilots, they just can't get the job done Got to fly down into the canyons, you'll never see the sun There's no such thing as an easy run for a treetop flyer Go fifteen feet over the Rio Grande I'll blow the mesquite right up of off the sand Seldom seen, especially when I land....I'm a treetop flyer...born survivor Well there's things I am, and there's things I'm not I'm not a ball-smuggler so I could get shot But I aint going to die, I ain't goin' to get caught, See I'm a flyin' fool, and my Staggerwing's way too hot....I'm a treetop flyer; born survivor, usually work alone.
